Document.name: Oregon Trail Trip
Document.description: Following the trail as much as possible from east to west, taking about a month to do it correctly. I will be doing some of the Sublette Cutoff route. I will not be going to Fort Bridger.

Placemark.name: Official start of the Oregon Trail
Placemark.description:
Official start of the Oregon Trail, where
wagons were outfitted through much of
the emigration era. Open year-round;
business hours vary.

Placemark.name: Santa Fe Trail Park
Placemark.description:
45-acre park preserving one-quarter
mile of ruts and swales.

Placemark.name: Point A
Placemark.description: US-24 follows the trail between Rossville and Silver Lake. From Rossville to St. Mary's, the highway is on top of the trail.

Placemark.name: Point B
Placemark.description: US-24 follows the trail between Rossville and Silver Lake. The actual trail was just to the north.

Placemark.name: Oregon Trail Nature Park
Placemark.description:
On the Oregon Trail route, and offers nature trails and a view of the winding
road that overlies the old Oregon Trail. The nature park is open to the public
May 1-Sept. 30, 7 a.m. – 9 p.m.; and Oct. 1-April 30, 8 a.m. – 6 p.m.

Placemark.name: Cholera Cemetary
Placemark.description:
Red Vermillion Crossing / Vieux
Cemetery/Cholera Cemetery (near
Belvue, KS) is the site on the Red Vermillion
where Louis Vieux, a Potawatomi
Indian, established a toll bridge in 1847.
In 1849, a large wagon train camped on
the east side of the creek was struck by
cholera, which left 50 emigrants dead
within a week. They were buried nearby.
The Vieux family cemetery is also in the
vicinity. Exhibits interpret the sites

Approx location. Don't block gate when parking.

Placemark.name: Alcove Spring
Placemark.description:
Has been called the
most significant historic site on the
Oregon Trail within the State of
Kansas. The scenic spring was a
popular campsite, mentioned in
many emigrant journals. Also at
about this location, emigrants left
the tallgrass prairie of eastern
Kansas and entered the shortgrass
plains. Access to this privately
owned site is provided by the Alcove
Spring Historical Trust.

Placemark.name: Hollenberg Station
Placemark.description:
Seven-acre state park and
national historic landmark that boasts
the only Pony Express station in
Kansas remaining in its original location.
It was initially built in 1857 as a
waystation to serve emigrant traffic on
the Oregon and California trails. The
site also offers a picnic area, nature
trail, museum, historical markers and
monuments. Open Wed.-Sat., 10 a.m. –
5 p.m.; Sun., 1 – 5 p.m.

Placemark.name: Rock Creek Station
Placemark.description:
Best known as the Pony Express station where Wild Bill Hickok shot 3 men. Also, a road ranch serving Oregon and California emigrants.

Exhibits, reconstructed buildings, graves and ruts

Placemark.name: George Winslow Grave
Placemark.description:
Interpretive sign.

Walk in through gate.

Placemark.name: Susan Haile Grave
Placemark.description:
35 years old and the mother of 6 children.

Interpretive sign

Approx location. North side of road.

Placemark.name: O'Fallens Bluff Trail Ruts and Interpretive Area
Placemark.description:
Westbound-Exit 158 to eastbound I-84

Then, exit at Exit 164 to return westbound

Placemark.name: California Hill ruts
Placemark.description: A half-mile up this road leads you to a way to see the ruts. Left side of road.

Placemark.description:
CLOSED

Many emigrants camped near the banks of the creek. They also died there and buried their dead.

Placemark.name: Cold Springs and Rifle Pit Hill
Placemark.description: Campsite and installation where soldiers protected the emigrants

Placemark.name: Red Buttes Crossing/Bessemer Bend Crossing
Placemark.description: Emigrants crossed here over the North Platte for the last time heading toward South Pass

Placemark.description: 6.3 miles

Placemark.description: 8.5 miles

Placemark.name: Thomas Fork
Placemark.description: Look west for ruts, also on surrounding hillsides

Placemark.name: Big Hill
Placemark.description: Look west up the hill between powerlines

Placemark.name: Snake River overlook
Placemark.description: Westbound access only. Access from Massacre Rocks SP

Placemark.name: Register Rock
Placemark.description: Inscriptions

Placemark.name: Evil Knievel Snake River Jump
Placemark.description: Look for signs to visitor center

Placemark.name: Lava Hot Springs
Placemark.description: Formerly part of the Fort Hall Indian Reservation, the hot springs were sold to U.S. Government, then later ceded to the State of Idaho. Soak in world famous hot pools, or take a dip at the Olympic Swimming Complex. The South Bannock County Historical Center offers a complete history of the area. Explore the nearby Portneuf River for tubing, or take in a wide range of outdoor activities like hiking trails, fishing, hunting, skiing and snowmobiling. Located along Hwy 30. 42°37'10.30"N, 112° 0'25.96"W

Placemark.name: Lower Portneuf River Sportsman’s Access
Placemark.description: This site offers wildlife viewing, fishing, and (further up the river) kayaking and canoeing. The Portneuf River was named after a mountain man by the name of Portneuf from Peter Skene Ogden’s trapper party. On Old Highway 30 two miles north of U.S. 30. A loop road provides a place to park and a moderate walk on an undeveloped trail to Portneuf River Falls. 42°38'28.02"N, 112° 0'23.11"W

Placemark.name: Hudspeth’s Cutoff
Placemark.description:
White fiberglass posts identify the Oregon-California Trail. Turn north the intersection of Idaho 34 and U.S. 30, then turn left through the park-and-ride lot and follow the old asphalt highway.
42°39'4.93"N, 111°43'43.01"W

Placemark.name: Wagon Ruts and Trail Markers
Placemark.description: Oregon Trail Park on the shore of Alexander Reservoir, reveals shallow swale remnants from wagons bound for Oregon and California. Accessible and easily visible from the park entrance road, the trail provokes the memories of those who traveled it. 42°39'31.89"N, 111°39'0.35"W.

Placemark.name: Wagon Box Grave
Placemark.description: Fairview Cemetery in Soda Springs - Mile 0.2, Located in the Fairview Cemetery one block west of downtown Soda Springs, the grave marks the burial site of an Oregon-bound emigrant family allegedly killed by Indians and buried here in their wagon box by other emigrants.

Placemark.name: Pyramid Springs and Soda Springs Geyser
Placemark.description:
Soda Springs boasts having the world's only captive geyser. On November 30, 1937 in an attempt to find a hot water source for a local swimming pool, a well driller set free the natural geyser at a depth of 317 feet. It is located on Pyramid Spring, a travertine mound described by Fremont in his 1840s expeditions, along with other area springs. The history of Soda Springs and Caribou County is portrayed on picture boards in the Geyser Park Visitor Center. Historical artifacts and antiques are on display next door at the Enders Hotel Museum. Enter on Main Street & 1st Street South and drive 150 feet west to Geyser Park.
42°39'26.13"N, 111°36'17.32"W

Placemark.name: Georgetown Summit
Placemark.description:
Over 300,000 emigrants used the Oregon-California Trail between 1840 and 1869. Three ruts are visible at the bottom of the hill, indicating that the wagons and oxen spread out to reduce the dust. The route crossed over this summit heading northwesterly for Soda Springs, and then went on to the Snake River at Hudson Bay Company’s Fort Hall. On U.S. 30, 3 miles north of Georgetown. 42 31.762 N, 111 24.336 W

The trail pretty muchs paralels the highway to Soda Springs.

Placemark.name: Oregon-California Trail Portal - Big Hill
Placemark.description: Emigrants by the thousands entered present day eastern Idaho at this location traveling along the Oregon-California Trail. Emigrants on the trail encountered Big Hill, thought to be the steepest and longest descent found on the trip west. Wheel ruts are still visible today from the locking of wagon wheels. East of Montpelier at ITD roadside pullouts on U.S. 30 (Milepost 440.1, Milepost 441.7 and Milepost 454.5). N 42 14 09.73, W 111 13 59.27

Placemark.name: Louis Vieux Tree, Kansas
Placemark.description:
Louis Vieux moved to this area about 1848 and ran a toll bridge over the river. The toll was $1 a wagon and some days he made $300 in tolls. He also sold some basic supplies to the emigrants.




This tree was seen by the emigrants as they passed. At the time of the Oregon Trail, this tree was about 130 years old and was quite large; stunning in a land of stunted trees and brush. In recent years, since this picture was taken in 1993, the tree has been struck by lightning and vandalized. It still lives but is no longer this size and shape.

Placemark.name: 1000 Springs, Idaho
Placemark.description:
The emigrants traveled along the Snake River for quite a ways in Idaho. The walls along part of the Snake are black volcanic rock from which gush white water for several miles. It is quite a sight.




Due to diversions of rain and melt water, there are fewer springs now than during the heyday of the Oregon Trail and may be fewer than shown in this picture taken in 1993.

Placemark.name: Laurel Hill

Placemark.name: Pony Express station
Placemark.description: Look toward Horse Creek for steel post marking where the station was.

Placemark.name: C
